substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though being inorganic compounds containing chlorine

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the LD50 value of 195mg/kg calculated from the testing data of rat LD50 (oral route) of 430mg/kg, 529mg/kg, 210mg/kg and 175mg/kg (ECETOC TR33 1989)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in EHC 108 (1991): "When aqueous solutions of nickel chloride were applied to the back, the threshold concentrations for irritancy were 1% with occlusion and 10% without occlusion." Also based on the evidence of skin irritation in humans (though the severity of the effects is unknown).

respiratory_skin_sensitizer.classification: Respiratory sensitizer: Category 1 Skin sensitizer: Category 1
respiratory_skin_sensitizer.rationale: Respiratory sensitizer: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as a Respiratory Sensitizing Substance by DFG (MAK/BAT (2005)) and "Respiratory Sensitizing Substance: Group 2" (as nickel compounds) according to the Recommendation on Occupational Exposure Limits for Chemical Substances (Japan Society for Occupational Health (2005)). Skin sensitizer: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as a Skin Sensitizing Substance by DFG (MAK/BAT (2005)) and "Skin Sensitizing Substance: Group 1" (as nickel compounds) according to the Recommendation on Occupational Exposure Limits for Chemical Substances (Japan Society for Occupational Health (2005)).

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on negative data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests (dominant lethal tests) and the absence of data on germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo and germ cell genotoxicity tests in vivo, and positive data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (chromosome aberration tests), described in IARC 49 (1990), EHC 108 (1991), ECETOC 33 (1989) and ATSDR (2005).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category K (as nickel compounds) by NTP (2005) and Category 1 (as nickel compounds) by IARC (1990).

toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: Based on the evidence of adverse effects on the reproductive function of parental animals and pup development, described in ATSDR (2005), IARC 49 (1990) and EHC 108 (1991). As for the reproductive/developmental toxicity of water-soluble inorganic nickel compounds, refer to "ID453, Nickel Sulfate, CAS: 7786-81-4."

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "nausea, abdominal spasm, diarrhea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, debility and myalgia" (ATSDR (2005)). The acute toxicity of nickel compounds manifests in humans as "nausea, diarrhea, dizziness, headache" (ECETOC TR33 (1989)).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organs/systemic toxicity following repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "elevated urinary beta2-microglobulin levels" (ATSDR (2005)) and the evidence from animal studies including "hyperplasia of the bronchial epithelium, marked reduction of seminiferous tubule diameter" (ATSDR (2005)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1. Chronic exposure to nickel and its compounds may produce respiratory irritation and degeneration in humans even at doses close to occupational exposure limits. Prolonged exposure to high concentrations is likely to result in the fibroid lung (ECETOC TR33 (1989)).

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 48 hours LC50=0.013mg/L of the crustacea (Ceriodaphnia) (ECETOC TR91, 2003).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since acute toxicity was Category 1 and it was a metallic compound, and since an underwater action and bio-accumulation were unknown, it was classified into Category 1.
